awd_titl_txt: S&AS: FND: COLLAB: Planning and Control of Heterogeneous Robot Teams for Ocean Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots in marine and littoral environments are envisioned for commerce, scientific exploration, search and rescue, and many other tasks. However, robots in such environments face significant challenges. Vehicles must act and effect change in environments with large inertial effects and disturbances, with only near-field perception. Coupled with our limited understanding of ocean dynamics and the lack of accessible and high-quality ocean flow data, these obstacles make the use of robotics technology in these varied applications extremely difficult. This project realizes an integrated, heterogeneous robotic approach towards large-scale ocean monitoring for environmental mitigation and search and rescue operations. It enables data-driven tracking and mapping of various physical, chemical, and/or biological processes of interest in marine environments, such as tracking contaminant dispersion or missing aircraft. This project significantly improves the state of the art in ocean search and monitoring technology, helping us understand and harness ocean currents, and improve the health of the world's oceans. Results from the project are integrated into education, through the PIs' courses, mentoring students on research, and expanding an existing K-12 outreach relationship. 
 
The project creates fundamental knowledge about new ways that robots can better monitor, sense, and operate in dynamic and uncertain environments. The project develops new methods for heterogeneous teams of monitoring robots to improve their environment model through current interactions with the environment; concurrently collect data, process and assimilate it into the existing model, and plan on that model; accept high-level instruction and translate goal-oriented directives such as environmental monitoring into a suitable plan for sensing, reasoning, communicating, and acting through the underlying system architecture; and monitor their actions, optimize, and reconfigure autonomously. The heterogeneous team of robots proposed includes surface vehicles providing samples at the air-sea interface and aerial robots creating flow models and acting as intermediaries within the team. The hierarchical structure of the approach takes advantage of the natural boundaries defined by Lagrangian coherent structures in the creation of a distributed sensing framework.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The project “S&AS: FND: COLLAB: Planning and Control of Heterogeneous Robot Teams for Ocean Monitoring” resulted in several publications and novel results for navigating teams of robots in a cluttered environment. It also resulted in training several PhD students at the University of Southern California as well as Brown University, who completed the research while also supervising several undergraduates, who received invaluable research experience. 

There are two novel algorithms that were developed under this grant that were published in several venues. The first is a fully distributed algorithm that allows robots to navigate through a cluttered environment without communication, and relying on sensing alone [1,2]. In this work, we improved over the state of the art algorithms for fully distributed multi-robot navigation, by separating the space between robots to create safe corridors for navigation. Our result, RLSS (Real-time, decentralized, cooperative, networkless multi-robot trajectory planning using Linear Spatial Separations) removes reliance on communication to prevent collision and deadlocks, while considerably decreasing the occurrence of collisions and deadlocks when large number of robots share a cluttered environment. 

The second algorithm is a hierarchical algorithm that allows a large number of robots to navigate a large area, e.g., for drone-based package delivery, that is locally centralized (requires communication within regions and across regions) but does not require long-distance communication. In this work, a large space is divided into smaller regions, which are tessellated into a discrete graph. Within each region, robots plan together in a centralized way to get to their respective next regions. The only communication between regions is robots giving advance notice to their next region about when and where they will arrive. Robots may enter and exit the environment; this initiates replanning with a multi-commodity flow algorithm within each region that occurs in real time. We demonstrate the algorithm with up to 142 robots, and have laid groundwork for the future wherein we will explore planning for smooth navigation (rather than on a discrete graph). This work was submitted for publication and is currently under review [3]. 

The intellectual merit of this work lies in the novel algorithms that allow large teams of robots to safely navigate cluttered environments, one in a fully distributed way, and one in a locally centralized way. These results pave the way for large scale robot deployments, such as in environmental monitoring, package delivery, structure inspection, etc. The broader impacts of the work are the application to these scenarios, as well as the significant training that the PhD and undergraduate students received in research and mentoring. Furthermore, the students participated in many outreach activities, including robotics demonstrations to local youth through several programs and lab visits. 

Publications:

[1] B. Şenbaşlar, W. Hönig, and N. Ayanian, “Robust trajectory execution for multi-robot teams using distributed real-time replanning,” in proceedings of Distributed Autonomous Robotic Systems, 2019, pp 167-181.

[2] B. Şenbaşlar, W. Hönig, and N. Ayanian, “RLSS: real-time, decentralized, cooperative, networkless multi-robot trajectory planning using linear spatial separations,” Auton Robot 47, 921–946 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10514-023-10104-w 

[3] L. Pan, K. Hsu, and N. Ayanian, “Hierarchical Large Scale Multirobot Path (Re)Planning,” submitted, under review. 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/13/2024
Modified by: Nora Ayanian

    Lishuo Pan, Kevin Hsu, Nora Ayanian
    Copyrighted

  • A long exposure photograph of 32 quadrotors navigating a cluttered environment using the hierarchical large scale multi robot path planner.
    Lishuo Pan, Kevin Hsu, Nora Ayanian
    Copyrighted

    Long Exposure Experiment
